title-group.article-title: Isolated Double Orifice Mitral Valve - a Rare Finding in an Elderly Man

article-meta.aff: 1University of Medicine and Pharmacy Carol Davila, Bucharest / Cardiology Department, University and Emergency Hospital of Bucharest - Romania
2National Institute of Pathology Victor Babes, Bucharest - Romania
3King Faisal Cardiac Centre, National Guard Health City, Jeddah - Saudia Arabia
4Duke Clinical Research Institute, Duke University Medical Center, Durham - USA

author-notes.corresp: Mailing Address: Dragos Vinereanu, University and Emergency Hospital Bucharest. University of Medicine and Pharmacy Carol Davila, Sector 5. Postal Code 050098, Bucharest, Bucharest - Romania. E-mail: vinereanu@gmail.com

license.license-p: This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution NonCommercial License which permits unrestricted noncommercial use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium provided the original work is properly cited.

body.p: We present herein several transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) images of a 60-year-old man referred to the cardiac surgeon for a triple coronary artery bypass graft procedure, in which a normally-functioning double orifice mitral valve (DOMV) was an incidental finding during routine intraoperative TEE. This is a very rare congenital malformation, even rarer as an isolated anomaly in an elderly patient. Three-dimensional TEE (3D-TEE) confirmed the diagnosis and provided complete and fast assessment of the mitral valve and the surrounding structures and all the information needed to reassess the surgical strategy in the very short pre‑bypass period.

fn.p: Conception and design of the research:Ciobanu AO, Bennett S, Vinereanu D. Acquisition of data:Ciobanu AO, Bennett S. Analysis and interpretation of the data: Ciobanu AO, Bennett S, Lopes RD, Vinereanu D. Writing of the manuscript:Ciobanu AO. No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.
There were no external funding sources for this study.
This study is not associated with any thesis or dissertation work.

caption.p: Real-time 3D-transesophageal echocardiogram „en face" view from the left atrium („surgeon's view", Panel A) and from the LV (Panel B) revealing two asymmetrical orifices, a smaller lateral (1) and a bigger medial (2) mitral orifice, separated by fibrous tissue (arrow). Panel C- achieved after using a sagittal crosssectional plane to "split" the valve and the LV in two for better view of the orifices and unrestricted opening of the mitral valve. Panel D. 2D (left) and 3D-zoom mode (right) transgastric view of the two orifices. LV, left ventricle.
